body: @rabbah - Perhaps there's a technical reason/cost for restricting media-type form data and json, but IMHO it's beneficial to support as many as possible so an API developer is free choose whatever content type is desired.

There's added complexity to the code. Before we support the kitchen sink we should at least make sure we support the common cases first and do them well. So I'm curious if there's an actual need for this vs let's do it to be general.
i agree with @mdeuser and @bjustin-ibm . providing access to the req body is the most generic approach, that provides most flexibility. content-type specific specializations can be layered on top.

Not sure this would help reduce the complexity... the json/formdata media-types can be considered "first class" content (i.e. content is parsed for parameters), while all other media-types are "second class" in that no parameter parsing is provided - the action gets the entire payload as-is in a single json field.  Although, I don't know if the as-is will involve encode/decode of the payload
@mdeuser, can you review this while I try to get a good PG?

@domdom82 PG1-1190 failed significantly.  Can you rebase and re-run or figure out what's wrong with it?
Duplicate of https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1886.
I suspect Cookie Monster 🍪 🍪

another odd variant of this:

if i nodejs request with `json: true, body: data` to a web-exported route `/my-action.text`, then i get back the "requires authentication" error. whereas if i use `headers: {content-type: 'application/json'}, body: JSON.stringify(data)` then things are happy.

this is i assume due to `json:true` also setting up the `accept` headers? i'm not sure, but this one was pretty opaque.

Going to be tricky to find who is eating those bytes. 

Any possible clashing with query parameters?
@perryibm I believe this is ready unless you have any other concerns or suggestions.
i've already verified that the squashing is unrelated to the size of the normal or cookie payloads. it's pretty weird, and a complete mystery to me, so far.
I removed the additional (redundant) logging in f2fc12b8e25a64255eb17cd62a61f49b9a29d47c and then squashed everything into one commit.
PG1-1200 green.
@starpit, this will happen as the content type must be JSON or Form Data.

A JSON:true option will set the content type to JSON. The puzzling thing is that whisk still rejects. I am guessing that this due to a mismatch of Accept. Because we are invoking with a .Text web exported suffix.
Can you post here the HTTP header being sent when you do a request with `json: true`?
@starpit that's consistent with this issue.
Besides the two comments above, the PR looks good since we already reviewed it.

The wording is ok but I'm not in favor of reporting this as an error because it's not consistent with the API response. 20x is success and errors from the controller are accompanied by both the error message and the transaction code.
@csantanapr - review complete.  travi/pg passed.  ready for merging, please
why are there references to Bluemix here?

@mdeuser see comment
> why are there references to Bluemix here?
@dubeejw i just verified: the difference seems to boil down to passing an `Accept: application/json` header, when invoking as `.text`
@l2fprod, you're not alone :)
@dubeejw want to take this one?
@rabbah the weird thing to me is that text *is* valid JSON. so an Accept: application/json should not be incompatible with a .text invocation?
Looks like the globalized strings must be merged during the build process as well..

Does it reproduce with API gw?
Any test cases to try?

Did you try to disable TLS for nodered? :

Try that by exporting NODE_TLS_REJECT_UNAUTHORIZED = "0" in your environment.
Lastly, you can use http://172.17.0.1:10001 instead as your openwhisk API host.

I double-checked both invoker machines:

```
cusina@openwhisk-pg1-vm3:~$ docker ps
CONTAINER ID        IMAGE               COMMAND             CREATED             STATUS              PORTS               NAMES
cusina@openwhisk-pg1-vm3:~$ sudo su
root@openwhisk-pg1-vm3:/home/cusina# docker-runc list

cusina@openwhisk-pg1-vm2:~$ docker ps
CONTAINER ID        IMAGE               COMMAND             CREATED             STATUS              PORTS               NAMES
cusina@openwhisk-pg1-vm2:~$ sudo su
root@openwhisk-pg1-vm2:/home/cusina# docker-runc list
ID          PID         STATUS      BUNDLE      CREATED
root@openwhisk-pg1-vm2:/home/cusina#
```

both are clean now.

Hi @sebgl thanks for the contribution great to see your PR

Could you submit an Apache iCLA? This is the projects policy 
All contributors must sign and submit an Apache CLA (Contributor License Agreement).

Instructions on how to do this can be found here: http://www.apache.org/licenses/#clas

Once submitted, you will receive a confirmation email from the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) and be added to the following list: http://people.apache.org/unlistedclas.html.

Project committers will use this list to verify pull requests (PRs) come from contributors that have signed a CLA.

We look forward to your contributions!

More info on CONTRIBUTING.md file on the root of the project

> nuking namespaces
Could someone provide some insight into what this means?

Thanks
pj
See this pr https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1914.

But when one creates a user/subject in a particular namespace, it will have its own authkey. So the command wsk namespace list will list the namespace under which the current user is created. How does a particular user have access to multiple namespace when the auth key is different. Or how do u create access for the current user in multiple namespaces ?
merged
See pr https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1914. Once merged the key will only see its namespace.
currently how is a user/subject identified in different namespaces ?

@g12megha currently there is a bit of ambiguity with regards to access to namespaces. Currently, a subject has access to each namespace in its subject record with each of the keys stored in there.

#1914 will get away with this and only make the namespace accessible that corresponds to the API key you use (modulo public packages etc. of course)

@csantanapr I reorganized and squashed into two separate commits: the first deprecates the runtime, the second removes the proxy/stops building it. It may be worth keeping the two commits separate in case we just need to revert the second but not the first.
Sounds good 👌 that's why I asked
Good catch.

It seems the CLI ignores 60000 - not to sound like a broken record but the CLI should not try to be too smart wrt the API. 

```
./cli/go-whisk-cli/commands/action.go:  if flags.action.memory != MEMORY_LIMIT || flags.action.timeout != TIMEOUT_LIMIT ||
```

This should be removed.
Made this issue an ZenHub epic with children #1309 and #1677
We need to put in the information in content.json first to be able to query the latest version from the CLI.
